comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
J. Ross Portrait Artist and Photographer (see note almost top left) -
Ross 54 Grafton Street, Dublin According to the company’s website, they were established in 1929. A photograph dated to 1930 is captioned: ‘Shadowgraph Portrait by J. Ross, 54 Grafton Street, Dublin’. There had been no photographer at this address in 1929, but ‘J. Ross, photographer’ was listed in 1931. By 1936, Ross Studios were at 3 St. Stephen’s Green. They were still there in 1974, but have since returned to Grafton Street, No 59, as Edmund Ross Studios.
From www.irisharchaeology.info/genealogy/photographers.html

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Definitely post-1925 as there was a clothes shop above Noblett's in May 1924 (from advert in the Irish Independent). The hairdressers were (was?) advertising for staff from October 1925 in the same newspaper. The proprietor was Alfonso Palcic, and you can see his name faintly over the window proclaiming "Gentlemens Hair Dressing".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The DIA has two references to 52, plans in 1931 and the entry Danny has above, saying Reconstruction started in October 1932. So this picture is latest 1932.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The policeman on duty is wearing a "forage" cap and a "duty band" on his wrist which would be a combination of the DMP and the Garda which happened in 1925.  But that is not definitive as the DMG (Dublin Metropolitan Gardai) continued to wear the helmets up to the early 50's!  Chances are the traffic guard wore the cap as it was less likely to fall off or be an irritation when he needed to turn suddenly to deal with a stupid driver.  Nice shot Carol, great choice.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Whose Grafton bar is at extreme left? This was where Rice's used to be, on the corner of Stephen's green and South King Street, until that alien spaceship thing landed on that corner. Edit: Looks like *RELLY, maybe FARRELLY'S? It should be about the same length as THE GRAFTON FARRELLY'S

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There was a photographer in 52 previously, a Forbes: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000168705/Image?lookfor=http:...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: And from the era of the tall electric lights (~1910): catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000168731/Image?lookfor=http:...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the tall electric light version, we can see that 141 St. Stephen's Green West, the pub on the corner, was called Bolgers. If we knew when Bolger's gave way to Farrelly's (or whatever) it might help.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: For completeness, Robert Forbes, photographer, is on Grafton Street in the 1901 census, but has moved to Greystones (artist) in 1911.

comment._content: On the Grafton Bar: Come here to me says Formally called Eamon Nolans (late 1950s), The Four Provinces (mid 1950s) and The Grafton Bar (1940s), it was taken over by publican Robert ‘Bobby’ Rice in 1960.

comment.author: 108350826@N06
comment._content:
My Uncle and my Dad were the founder members of the Ross Studios . I think
I found a 1926 picture once but can't swear on it . But  1929 on for
definite . Family born in Belfast .J Ross founder and my Dad David about 3
years after . Both trained artists .yes first studio 54 Grafton st followed
shortly after 3 St Stephens Green  then Edmund Ross opened at age 24 yrs in
and cont till 1963 ChathamStreet   then 1968    59 Grafton St for 50 years
Edmund opened latest studio this year at 11 St Stephens Green .
My parents the founders ,are the sons of Russian Jewish Family who settled
in Belfast 1890   .pedalling  goods, as It was difficult at the time to get
employed especially being Jewish

Kind Regards


Edmund

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/108350826@N06] No need to apologise, Edmund! Thanks a million for all of this information - there's nothing quite like hearing directly from a family member. So for now, this photograph can happily stay at a date of between 1929-32.

Hope you enjoyed seeing this tiny snippet of your family history...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/108350826@N06] Thanks EdmundRoss.  84+ years of Dublin photography! - how about posting some of your favourites to Flickr for the Flickroonies to chatter over?  Please!
